Tested section?
this has been unit tested and functionality testing being done on systems as well

Hi Ankita, 
I had removed tested section from earlier commits because @arj did not feel it necessary for libpldm when unit tests have been added. I have however added it here. Will wait for his feedback and add in other commits
Done
Hi Varsha, I have a few comments. Nothing terribly structural, but there are some misunderstandings in there that I've hopefully addressed.
What value might be too large?
Done
Why did we chop out all the vowels of "handle"?
Done
Can we not assert these given the function is static? Also need to account for `record_handle`?
Done
Please declare the variables before any code to keep the formatting idiomatic.
Done
Please use `pldm_msgbuf_extract()`.
Done
Please do not do any pointer arithmetic when initialising the msgbuf object. You can use `pldm_msgbuf_span_required()` to skip over any unwanted regions for now.
Done
Please no, these should all just be `pldm_msgbuf_extract()`. Spans are for "opaque" regions of memory; here you're trying to actually use them, and the endianness handling is broken.
Done
`LIBPLDM_ABI_TESTING`.
Done
What about `pdr_record_handle`?
Done
Please declare the variables before any code.
Done
we're not adding, right? We're removing?
Done
We decrement it below...
Done
We decrement it below...
Done
These all must be `pldm_msgbuf_extract()` for the reasons outlined in the static function above.
Done
Done
Perhaps a new line above this label would be helpful for readability.
Done
Please don't combine all the tests under one ifdef - they should each have their own.
Done
Hi Varsha, I have a few queries and concerns inline.
Where does the pointer come from? Do you have an example of how this API will be used in practice?

Right, I think this sounds okay. I'd just like to document here in the doxygen comment that the values in the struct pointed to by `entity` must be in "host" endianness (... as-in, BMC CPU endianness if libpldm is being used on a BMC), just to be explicit.
Done
I had to add this check to get the CI to pass
Interesting. Let me experiment with that.
Done
Please no pointer arithmetic here. Use `pldm_msgbuf_span_required()` to skip over a range of memory.
Done
I expect because of the pointer arithmetic above, using `record->size` here will allow for a buffer overflow.
Done
Please no pointer arithmetic here. See the comment above.
Done
See the overflow comment above.
Done
I asked where the `entity` pointer comes from, because depending on the answer, the endianness for the comparison may or may not be correct here.
I dont think it is required. see comment in pdr.h. I will correct it if I a wrong in next review
Nope, all good, just the change to the doxygen as discussed in the header.
Done
Done
Hi Varsha, I've left a few comments. Thanks for the discussion about the entity parameter, that was quite helpful.
Hmm. I wonder if we should allow it to accept `NULL` as an argument. Or add `pldm_msgbuf_skip(struct pldm_msgbuf *ctx, size_t len)`
in pldm_msgbuf_span_required, no harm is caused of cursor can be allowed to be NULL. IMO
Can you push a patch doing so?
Done
Done
Probably best to use calloc()
Done
Hi Varsha, this continues to improve. I have a few more suggestions.

Can we please move these declarations into the for-loop below to reduce the scope?

However, looking more closely, this is just an exploded `struct pldm_entity`. We can just declare a variable of that type instead and assign into its members?
Done
If you change `pldm_msgbuf_span_require()` to allow `NULL` for the cursor then we can drop these.
Done
I commented below about how this needs to happen at the end of each loop iteration. Perhaps if we move the code down and give it a label we can use a goto for cleanup here.
Done
Done

If we use a `struct pldm_entity` instead and switch the `pldm_msgbuf_extract()` calls to assign into its members, like:

```
struct pldm_entity curr;
...
pldm_msgbuf_extract(dst, curr.entity_type);
...
```

Then this condition can just be `if (entity == curr)` which saves the visual mess.

I think there is no way to compare two structures in C we have to compare each member (as per stack overflow). So I have kept the variable definition just before the for loop to reduce its scope. 

Also unable to declare the structure as pldm_entity curr instead of declaring each individual member because extract returns -ENIVAL complaining that curr.entity_type and other members is not set or initialized so it is NULL. I added traces to understand where it was failing.

> Also unable to declare the structure as pldm_entity curr instead of declaring each individual member because extract returns -ENIVAL complaining that curr.entity_type and other members is not set or initialized so it is NULL

Can you paste me the code you wrote? And the errors that you received?
figured it out , sorry about the delay. The problem is fixed
Done
This needs to happen at the end of each iteration of the `while()` loop, right? Can you move this down after line 1743 below?
Done
Hi Varsha, I have a few queries inline.
Why is this a pointer if it's an in-parameter?
This is an in-out parameter
That seems surprising. Why is it an out-parameter? The documentation doesn't give any hint as to why that should be true.

I was wrong it is just an out parameter. Conventional way to call this API would be to make the API return the record handle because it is an out parameter instead of return code. But we would prefer the API return the rc because we call multiple other APIs inside it which may fail. That is the reason we have included the record handle as a pointer
Okay, but I think we're missing the justification for why the caller would need that information. Can you add the answer to the documentation?
Done
Move these inside the for-loop? There's no reason for them to be at the outer-scope.
Done
These need tests in the same way that the similar code above has. Also given the similarities, is there some way we could make it common?
Done
This seems surprising. I've re-opened the discussion on PS7.

It should be an out parameter. I was wrong abut in-out. In PLDM we initially it to 0 and call this API to remove the record, if this API returns a SUCCESS then PDR repo is updated that this particular record handle has been removed.
Added explanation in the commit message why record_handle should also be an out parameter
Why do we need `stdio.h`?
no we dont. added for debug and testing will remove
Ah, yes, I still need to understand this one. I rather think we need to improve the proof to the compiler.
Acknowledged

...drop the condition here, so we have:

```
...
container_id = htole16(container_id);
memcpy(container_id_addr, &container_id), sizeof(container_id));
...
```

That should deal with clang-tidy without requiring the runtime branch.
Done
We can directly return at this point? Just using `break;` here jumps us out of the for-loop, but not the outer while-loop.
Done
Hi Varsha, I've made a few small changes myself, but also have some queries for you.
I've pushed an update that extracts out your equality check here. I did that because I wanted to add the `LIBPLDM_CC_NONNULL` attribute macro. We can also use `pldm_entity_cmp()` below.
Acknowledged
Can you explain to me how this is used as an out-parameter?
yes I have explained in the pdr.h file
Here we use `pldm_entity_cmp()` again.
Acknowledged

Given we've used `pldm_msgbuf_extract()` above, these must be `pldm_msgbuf_insert(dst, e.*)`, otherwise you're copying from data at the wrong offset in `src`.

Your test cases should demonstrate correct behaviour here.

this was a bug in the code , and it was not caught because the unit test only checks the return value which is the record handle. I have enhanced the unit test a bit. There are no APIs yet to check each child entity values but I did add traces in the unit test to make sure I fixed this bug
I don't think we need any extra APIs, we can test the memory against a pre-defined array. This is subtle enough that I'd like tests to be added.
Done
Why? Can you please unpack this in the commit message?
Done
Can you rebase this change on top of main? I've merged a patch that added support for `__attribute__((nonnull))` (also this one is missing underscores, I'm surprised it worked).
Done

Can we leave this as a unassigned variable for now, so:

```
void *container_id;
```

And then below...
Done
...add `container_id_addr = NULL;` on the line above so it's visually local to where it's used.
Done

And then on the line below, add:

```
assert(container_id_addr);
```

and...
Done
`LIBPLDM_CC_NONNULL`
Done

We can just put these on the stack right? The struct is only 6 bytes. No need for malloc:

```
struct pldm_entity entities[4];
```
yes , but I have explained why this declaration is used here and in other unit tests below-
This is addressed with the above suggestion

yes but we need it for this use case. Because in this test we use pldm_entity_association_pdr_add_from_node_with_record_handle to set the record handle of the PDR added to the repo after the repo and tree are initialized.

pldm_entity_association_pdr_add_from_node_with_record_handle(pldm_entity_node *node, pldm_pdr *repo, pldm_entity **entities,
        size_t num_entities, bool is_remote, uint16_t terminus_handle,
        uint32_t record_handle)

Above API requires entities to be sent in double pointer type. So we need to define the PDR in pldm_entity* type so we can set the record handle. This record handle is checked with the initial value to validate if unit completed successfully

So we have defined entities in a similar way throughout this file only in places where we need to use pldm_entity_association_pdr_add_from_node_with_record_handle for setting the record handle.

So I'm poking at this a bit, and the first thing I find is that the doxygen for `pldm_entity_association_pdr_add_from_node_with_record_handle()` is inaccurate, as it also is for `pldm_entity_association_pdr_add_from_node()`.

Can you please send patches fixing it for both?

> Above API requires entities to be sent in double pointer type. So we need to define the PDR in pldm_entity* type so we can set the record handle. This record handle is checked with the initial value to validate if unit completed successfully

This isn't making sense to me. Can you walk me through why setting the record handle requires that entities is a double-pointer?

If we're allocating in the implementation and passing back out the pointer to the new memory, then this is sufficient, right?

```
struct pldm_entity entities[4] = { ... };
struct pldm_entity *base = entities;

...

pldm_entity_association_pdr_add_from_node_with_record_handle(..., &base, ...);

...
```

Also if we're passing out the pointer to the internally allocated object this way, aren't we leaking the original memory? Or do I have a misunderstanding there?

I have addressed this as you suggested. Will keep this in mind in future commits. Thank you for your review comment and explanation. I will add commit to fix doxygen for  pldm_entity_association_pdr_add_from_node_with_record_handle().
Done
Hi Varsha, the main issue is that you're going to trigger UB with some assignments. However, I've suggested the fix inline, and I hope that otherwise the comments are straight-forward to address.
This isn't part of the v0.9.0 release. Can you please move it up under the `## [Unreleased]` section above?
Done

You must not do this before you've tested that `repo` is not null. Please separate the assignments from the definitions of the variables, and do the assignments after the tests on 1765.

If you leave this as is the optimiser will delete the test for `repo` being NULL ("undefined behaviour must not happen, therefore as you've already dereferenced `repo` it mustn't be `NULL`, therefore the `NULL` check is redundant."). Hopefully you can see how that will proceed when someone passes `NULL` for repo 😊
Done
Nit: You can use designated initialisers here too.
Done
Hi Varsha, one minor issue. Thanks for the work so far.
Thank you the review comment, will follow this for future commits
